Question: Under what authority is the Gambling Regulation Act 2024 (Establishment Day) Order 2025 made, and what legal effect does it have upon commencement?

Passages.Passage: 1. This Order may be cited as the Gambling Regulation Act 2024 (Establishment Day) Order 2025.

Question: What specific date is appointed as the establishment day for the purposes of the Gambling Regulation Act 2024, and which Minister issued this Order?

Passages.Passage: 2. The 5th day of March 2025 is appointed to be the establishment day for the purposes of the Gambling Regulation Act 2024 (No. 35 of 2024). GIVEN under my Official Seal, 28 February, 2025. JIM O’CALLAGHAN, Minister for Justice.

Question: How do the Student Support Regulations 2025 define 'approved institutions' for purposes of grant eligibility under the Student Support Act 2011?

Passages.Passage: 3. (1) The institutions listed in Schedule 1 are 'approved institutions' under section 7(1)(a) to (d) of the Act. (2) The institutions listed in Schedule 2 are prescribed as 'approved institutions' for the purposes of section 7(1)(f) and (2) of the Act.

Question: Which categories of persons are newly prescribed as 'family members' or 'eligible persons' under section 14 of the Student Support Act 2011 by these Regulations?

Passages.Passage: 5. (1) The following family members are prescribed for the purposes of section 14(1)(d) of the Act— (a) a person who is a family member of a person referred to in section 14(1)(a) of the Act and has permission to remain in the State as a family member of such person under the provisions of the European Communities (Free Movement of Persons Regulations) 2006 and 2008 and Directive 2004/38/EC... (b) a person who has permission to remain in the State by virtue of marriage to, or a civil partnership with, an Irish national residing in the State, or as a dependent child of such a person...

Question: Who is appointed as Special Adviser under this Order, to which Minister is the appointment made, and from what date does it take effect?

Passages.Passage: 2. Craig Dwyer, particulars of whose address have been deposited at the offices of the Department of Social Protection, is appointed to be a Special Adviser to the Minister for Social Protection, with effect from 24 February 2025.

Question: What formal procedural steps accompany the appointment of a Special Adviser under this Order, and who signs it on behalf of the Government?

Passages.Passage: GIVEN under the Official Seal of the Government, 19 March, 2025. MICHEÁL MARTIN, Taoiseach. Notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in 'Iris Oifigiúil' of 21st March, 2025.

Question: What is the establishment day of An tÚdarás Póilíneachta agus Sábháilteachta Pobail as set by this Order, and under which Act is it constituted?

Passages.Passage: 2. The 2nd day of April 2025 is appointed to be the establishment day of An tÚdarás Póilíneachta agus Sábháilteachta Pobail for the purposes of the Policing, Security and Community Safety Act 2024. GIVEN under my Official Seal, 2 April, 2025. JIM O’CALLAGHAN, Minister for Justice.

Question: What statutory authority empowers the making of the Policing, Security and Community Safety Act 2024 (An tÚdarás Póilíneachta agus Sábháilteachta Pobail) (Establishment Day) Order 2025?

Passages.Passage: 1. This Order may be cited as the Policing, Security and Community Safety Act 2024 (An tÚdarás Póilíneachta agus Sábháilteachta Pobail) (Establishment Day) Order 2025.

Question: What types of misconduct are prescribed as 'notifiable misconduct' under the Policing, Security and Community Safety Act 2024 (Notifiable Misconduct) Regulations 2025?

Passages.Passage: 4. Each type of misconduct (within the meaning of paragraph (a) of the definition of misconduct in section 193(1) of the Act) – (a) specified in the Schedule, and (b) other than insofar as it is otherwise an incident of concern, is prescribed for the purposes of paragraph (b) of the definition of 'notifiable misconduct' in the said section 193(1).

Question: Which internal Garda Síochána policies are explicitly referenced as examples of notifiable misconduct obligations under these Regulations?

Passages.Passage: 3. Any failure by a member of An Garda Síochána to comply with an obligation imposed on him or her by any of the policy documents of An Garda Síochána for the time being known as: (a) 'Overarching Use of Force Policy of An Garda Síochána'; (b) 'Restraints and Handcuffs Policy of An Garda Síochána'; (c) 'Use of Batons Policy of An Garda Síochána'; (d) 'Deployment and Use of Less-Lethal Devices Policy of An Garda Síochána'; (e) 'Use of Force and Garda Horses Policy of An Garda Síochána'; (f) 'Use of Force and Garda Dogs Policy of An Garda Síochána'.

Question: When, notwithstanding Regulation 3, may a person lawfully perform acts that would otherwise constitute an offence under these Regulations?

Passages.Passage: 4. Notwithstanding Regulation 3, a person who has received an authorisation under an Article of the Council Regulation specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2 may, subject to compliance with the terms and conditions of such authorisation, do such of the things as are so authorised.

Question: In prosecutions for offences alleged to have been committed outside the State, what certificates constitute evidence that the accused was an Irish citizen on the relevant date?

Passages.Passage:
(3) In proceedings for an offence referred to in paragraph (1),
(a) a certificate purporting to be signed by an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and stating that a passport was issued by that Department to a person on a specified date, and
(b) a certificate that is signed by an officer of the Minister for Justice and stating that, to the best of the officer’s knowledge and belief, the person has not ceased to be an Irish citizen,
is evidence that the person was an Irish citizen on the date on which the offence is alleged to have been committed, and is taken to have been signed by the person purporting to have signed it, unless the contrary is shown.

Question: For a Notice of Appeal to the High Court sitting in Dublin, what core particulars must be stated about the parties and the decision appealed?

Passages.Passage:
NOTICE OF APPEAL TO HIGH COURT SITTING IN DUBLIN.
THE HIGH COURT
Between …………….A.B. ………………………………………...Plaintiff
and ………………….C.D. …………………………………………Defendant
Take notice that the defendant C.D. [or plaintiff A.B. or other person appealing] hereby appeals to the High Court, sitting in Dublin from the whole of the judgment of the Circuit Court given herein the ........... day of .............................,

Question: Where an appellant is not legally represented, what contact details must be provided in the Notice of Appeal form?

Passages.Passage:
If the Appellant is not legally represented please complete the following
Current postal address
Email address
Telephone No.

Question: Who must be served with an originating notice of motion seeking payment out of moneys lodged under section 459, and what must the grounding affidavit address?

Passages.Passage:
“(6) An originating notice of motion issued under section 459(10) or section 459(12) of the Act seeking an order for the payment out of all or any part of any moneys which were lodged under section 459(7)(c) or section 459(9)(b) of the Act shall be served on the offeree company concerned.

(7) An originating notice of motion under sub-rule (6) shall be grounded on an affidavit which sets out the basis of the applicant’s claim to be entitled to all or any part of any moneys concerned and verifies the facts, and exhibits and verifies any document, supporting the claim.

(8) The Court may direct service of an originating notice of motion under sub-rule (6) on any other person and may direct the filing of any affidavit by the respondent or any other person on notice of the application.”

Question: Before the Accountant authorises receipt of a lodgment under section 459, what information must the offeree company swear and file in its affidavit and schedule?
After this Order takes effect, how should statutory references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment and to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment be construed?

Passages.Passage:
4.
In any enactment or any instrument made under an enactment –
(a) references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment shall be construed as references to the Department of Enterprise, Tourism and Employment, and
(b) references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment shall be construed as references to the Minister for Enterprise, Tourism and Employment.

Question: What is the new English title of the Minister having charge of the Department following the alteration of name?

Passages.Passage: 3. The title of the Minister having charge of the Department of State, whose present title is, in the Irish language, an tAire Fiontar, Trádála agus Fostaíochta and, in the English language, the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment is altered, in the Irish language, to that of an tAire Fiontar, Turasóireachta agus Fostaíochta and, in the English language, to that of the Minister for Enterprise, Tourism and Employment.

Question: Which statutory function in relation to youth work is transferred from the Minister for Education, and to whom is it transferred?

Passages.Passage: 3. (1) The functions vested in the Minister for Education by or under section 18(4)(d) of the Youth Work Act 2001 (No. 42 of 2001) are transferred to the Minister for Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth.

Question: What is the effect of this Order on pending legal proceedings involving the Minister for Education that relate to functions transferred by the Order?

Passages.Passage: 4. Where, immediately before the commencement of this Order, any legal proceedings are pending to which the Minister for Education is a party and the proceedings have reference to functions transferred by this Order to the Minister for Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth, the name of the Minister for Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth shall, in so far as the proceedings relate to any function transferred by this Order, be substituted in the proceedings for that of the Minister for Education or added in the proceedings, as may be appropriate, and the proceedings shall not abate by reason of such substitution.

Question: What key amendments do these Regulations make to the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) Regulations 2022 regarding employer thresholds and reporting timelines?

Passages.Passage: 2. The Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) Regulations 2022 (S.I. No. 264 of 2022) are amended - (a) in Regulation 2, in the definition of “relevant employer”, by the substitution of “50” for “150”, and (b) in Regulation 6(1), by the substitution of “5 months” for “6 months”. GIVEN under my Official Seal, 27 May, 2025. NORMA FOLEY, Minister for Children, Equality and Disability.

Question: When do the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025 come into operation, and how should they be cited?

Passages.Passage: 1. (1) These Regulations may be cited as the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025. (2) These Regulations shall come into operation on 31 May 2025.

Question: Under this bye-law, what conflict-of-interest safeguards apply to the Returning Officer and scrutineers during the conduct of elections to the Social Care Workers Registration Board?

Passages.Passage: 4. (3) The Returning Officer will ensure, insofar as it is possible, that neither he or she, nor any person employed by him or her, has any conflict of interest, and will avoid any perceived conflict of interest, in relation to the running of the Election. Should a conflict of interest arise, in relation to the Returning Officer, he or she will immediately notify the Council and the substitute Returning Officer will take over the running of the Election... (6) The Returning Officer or any person appointed by him or her for any purpose relating to the Election shall not be a Candidate or a Relative of a Candidate... (7) The Returning Officer shall not appoint for any purpose relating to the Election a person who to the knowledge of the Returning Officer – (a) is or has been a Candidate, (b) has been associated in furthering the candidature of a Candidate, or (c) is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election.

Question: According to this bye-law, under what conditions may an election be postponed, rescheduled, or restarted by the Returning Officer, and what obligations exist for transparency in such cases?

Passages.Passage: 23. (1) Notwithstanding any contrary provision in this bye-law, the Returning Officer may, in any case in which it appears to him or her that there is an emergency or special difficulty, make such changes or modifications of any of the procedures set out herein for the conduct of the Election (including but not limited to rescheduling, postponing, or curtailing the applicable times and suspending the application of all or any part of the procedures) as may in his opinion be necessary or desirable to enable such Election to be duly held... (2) The Returning Officer shall, insofar as the circumstances permit, publish summary details of any such emergency, error or special difficulty and the changes or modifications to be made to any of the procedures set out herein for the conduct of the Election.

Question: What amendments are made to the District Court (Areas) Order 1961 concerning the days and times of court sittings in Nenagh and Thurles under this Order?

Passages.Passage: 2. The First Schedule to the District Court (Areas) Order, 1961 (S.I. No. 5 of 1961), is hereby amended by— the substitution at reference number 233 for the matter in column (4) of the following: “Nenagh —First and Fourth Monday in each month. First, Second, Third and Fourth Thursday in each month. First, Second, and Third Friday in each month. All sittings at 10.30 a.m.”, and the substitution at reference number 238 for the matter in column (4) of the following: “Thurles — First, Second, Third and Fourth Tuesday in each month. Third Wednesday in each month. All sittings at 10.30 a.m.”

Question: What procedural provision ensures continuity of District Court business initiated before this Order’s commencement?

Passages.Passage: 4. Business transacted in the District Court that is initiated and not completed before commencement of this Order shall be continued and completed as if this Order had been in force at the time at which such business had been initiated.

Question: Which statutory powers of the Minister for Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht are delegated under this Order, and to whom is the delegation made?

Passages.Passage: 2. The powers (other than the power to prosecute an offence) and duties of the Minister for Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht conferred on him – (a) by or under the provisions of the Acts of the Oireachtas specified in Part 1 of the Schedule, (b) under the instruments specified in Part 2 of the Schedule, and (c) by or under – (i) section 3A(b) of the Community, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2007 (No. 32 of 2007), ... are delegated to Jerry Buttimer, Minister of State at the Department of Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht.

Question: What statutes and statutory instruments fall within the scope of functions delegated under this Order, as listed in the Schedule?

Passages.Passage: SCHEDULE PART 1 Section 162 of the Public Health (Ireland) Act 1878 (41 & 42 Vict., c. 52) ... Charities (Amendment) Act 2024 (No. 21 of 2024) PART 2 Local Community Development Committee (Section 128E) Regulations 2014 (S.I. No 234 of 2014) Water Safety Ireland (Establishment) Order 2019 (S.I. No. 56 of 2019) (other than Articles 5, 6 and 7 of that Order).

Question: What new provision do these Regulations introduce for eligible vehicles concerning the design of registration plates and their CO2 emissions?

Passages.Passage: 4. The Regulations of 1992 are amended – (a) in Regulation 4 – (i) by inserting the following after the definition of “competent person”: “ ‘CO2 emissions’ has the same meaning as it has in section 130 of the Finance Act 1992 (No. 9 of 1992);”, ... (c) by inserting after Regulation 9(9) the following paragraph: “(10) Subject to paragraphs 12A, 16 and 17 of the First Schedule, an eligible vehicle may display a plate which contains a stripe which is green in colour.”

Question: According to the First Schedule amendments, what specifications govern the green stripe and character dimensions on eligible vehicle registration plates?

Passages.Passage: 5. The First Schedule to the Regulations of 1992 is amended – ... “12A. The green stripe for an eligible vehicle shall be colour Pantone 7481c or a colour match that is as close as possible to this colour and shall be formed of reflex reflective material.” ... “14. The identification mark shall appear in black characters and each letter or figure shall have a height of not less than 65 millimetres and not more than 70 millimetres. The stroke width of each letter or figure shall be not less than 9 millimetres and not more than 10 millimetres.”

Question: How do the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025 modify the definition of ‘relevant employer’ and the timeline for reporting obligations?

Passages.Passage: 2. The Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) Regulations 2022 (S.I. No. 264 of 2022) are amended - (a) in Regulation 2, in the definition of “relevant employer”, by the substitution of “50” for “150”, and (b) in Regulation 6(1), by the substitution of “5 months” for “6 months”.

Question: What is the citation and commencement date of the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025?

Passages.Passage: 1. (1) These Regulations may be cited as the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025. (2) These Regulations shall come into operation on 31 May 2025.

Question: What legal effect does Regulation 2 have in relation to the substances listed in the Schedule, and under which primary Act are they controlled?

Passages.Passage:
2. Each of the substances, products and preparations specified in the 
Schedule is hereby declared to be a controlled drug for the purposes of the 
Misuse of Drugs Act 1977 (No. 12 of 1977).

Passages.Passage:
N,N-diethyl-2-[(4-butoxyphenyl)methyl]-5-nitro-1H-benzimidazole-1ethanamine (otherwise known as Butonitazene 

N,N-diethyl-5-nitro-2-[(4-propoxyphenyl)methyl]-1-H-benzimidazole-1ethanamine (otherwise known as Protonitazene) 

2-[(4-Ethoxyphenyl)methyl]-N,N-diethyl-1H-benzimidazole-1-ethanamine 
(otherwise known as Etazene) 

2-[(4-Ethoxyphenyl)methyl]-5-nitro-1-(2-piperidin-1-ylethyl)-1Hbenzoimidazole (otherwise known as Etonitazepipne) 

2-[(4-Ethoxyphenyl)methyl]-5-nitro-1-(2-pyrrolidin-1-ylethyl)-1Hbenzoimidazole (otherwise known as Etonitazepyne) 

N-ethyl-2-[2-[(4-isopropoxyphenyl)methyl]-5-nitro-benzimidazol-1yl]ethanamine (otherwise known as N-desethyl isotonitazene) 

2-[(4-methoxyphenyl)methyl]-5-nitro-1-(2-pyrrolidin-1-ylethyl)-1Hbenzoimidazole (otherwise known as Metonitazepyne 

5-nitro-2-[(4-propoxyphenyl)methyl]-1-(2-pyrrolidin-1-ylethyl)benzimidazole 
(otherwise known as Protonitazepyne

Question: What specific additions are made to Schedule 1 of the Principal Regulations by Regulation 3, and how are those entries positioned relative to existing items?

Passages.Passage:
3. Schedule 1 to the Principal Regulations is amended, in paragraph 1(a), 

by – 

(a) the insertion of “N-[1-(Aminocarbonyl)-2,2-dimethylpropyl]-1butyl-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide (otherwise known as ADBBUTINACA)” after “N-(Adamantan-1-yl)-1-(5-fluoropentyl)1H-indazole-3-carboxamide (otherwise known as Clockwork 
Orange, 5F AKB48)”, 

(b) the insertion of “N,N-diethyl-2-[(4-butoxyphenyl)methyl]-5nitro-1H-benzimidazole-1-ethanamine (otherwise known as 
Butonitazene)” after “[2,3-Dihydro-5-methyl-3-(4morpholinylmethyl) pyrrolo[1,2,3-de]-1,4-benzoxazin-6-yl]-1naphthalenylmethanone”, 

(c) the insertion of “N,N-diethyl-5-nitro-2-[(4-propoxyphenyl) 
methyl]-1-H-benzimidazole-1-ethanamine (otherwise known as 
Protonitazene)” after “N,N-Diethyl-2-(2-(4-isopropoxybenzyl)5-nitro-1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)ethan-1-amine (otherwise 
known as Isotonitazene)”, 

(d) the insertion of the following after “1-(1,2Diphenylethyl)piperidine (otherwise known as Diphenidine)”: 

“2-[(4-Ethoxyphenyl)methyl]-N,N-diethyl-1H-benzimidazole-1ethanamine (otherwise known as Etazene) 

2-[(4-Ethoxyphenyl)methyl]-5-nitro-1-(2-piperidin-1-ylethyl)1H-benzoimidazole (otherwise known as Etonitazepipne) 

2-[(4-Ethoxyphenyl)methyl]-5-nitro-1-(2-pyrrolidin-1-ylethyl)1H-benzoimidazole (otherwise known as Etonitazepyne) 

N-ethyl-2-[2-[(4-isopropoxyphenyl)methyl]-5-nitrobenzimidazol-1-yl]ethanamine (otherwise known as N-desethyl 
isotonitazene)”, 

(e) the insertion of “2-(2-fluorophenyl)-2-(methylamino) 
cyclohexan-1-one (otherwise known as 2Fluorodeschloroketamine)” after “[1-(5-Fluoropentyl)-1H-indol3-yl] (2,2,3,3-tetramethylcyclopropyl) methanone (otherwise 
known as XLR-11)”, 

(f) the insertion of the following after “1-(4-Fluorophenyl)-2methylaminopropan-1-one”: 

“6a,7,8,9,10,10a-hexahydro-6,6,9-trimethyl-3-pentyl-6Hdibenzo [b,d]pyran-1-ol (otherwise known as 
Hexahydrocannabinol) 

Hexahydro derivatives of 3-alkyl homologues of cannabinol”, 

(g) the insertion of “2-[(4-methoxyphenyl)methyl]-5-nitro-1-(2pyrrolidin-1-ylethyl)-1H-benzoimidazole (otherwise known as 
Metonitazepyne)” after “1-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-2-(methylamino) 
propan-1-one”, and 

(h) the insertion of the following after “1-(4-Methylphenyl)-2methylaminopropan-1-one”: 

“1-{2-methyl-4-[(2E)-3-phenylprop-2-en-1-yl]piperazin-1yl}butan-1-one (otherwise known as 2-methyl-AP-237) 

5-nitro-2-[(4-propoxyphenyl)methyl]-1-(2-pyrrolidin-1ylethyl)benzimidazole (otherwise known as Protonitazepyne)”.

Question: Which substances are newly included in Schedule 4, Part 1 of the Principal Regulations by Regulation 4, and where are they inserted?

Passages.Passage:
4. Schedule 4 to the Principal Regulations is amended, in Part 1, by – 

(a) the insertion of “Bromazolam” after “Bromazepam”, and 

(b) the insertion of “Carisoprodol” after “Camazepam”.

Question: Which authority may issue written directions for administering and enforcing these Regulations and the Council Regulation, and what are the penalties for failing to comply within the specified time?

Passages.Passage:
6. A competent authority in the State, following such consultation as it 
considers necessary with other competent authorities, for the purposes of the 
administration and enforcement of the Council Regulation or these Regulations, 
may give in writing such directions to a person as it sees fit.

7. A person who fails to comply with a direction given under Regulation 6 
within the time specified in the direction shall be guilty of an offence and shall 
be liable on summary conviction to a class A fine or to imprisonment for a term 
not exceeding 6 months or both.

Question: For offences relating to acts committed outside the State, what procedural prerequisites apply and what documentary evidence is admissible to prove Irish citizenship of the accused?

Passages.Passage:
9. (1) Proceedings for an offence under these Regulations in relation to an 
act committed outside the State may be taken in any place in the State and the 
offence may for all incidental purposes be treated as having been committed in 
that place. 

(2) Where a person is charged with an offence referred to in paragraph (1), 
no further proceedings in the matter (other than any remand in custody or on 
bail) may be taken except by or with the consent of the Director of Public 
Prosecutions. 

(3) In proceedings for an offence referred to in paragraph (1), 
(a) a certificate purporting to be signed by an officer of the 
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and stating that a 
passport was issued by that Department to a person on a specified 
date, and 
(b) a certificate that is signed by an officer of the Minister for Justice, 
Home Affairs and Migration and stating that, to the best of the 
officer’s knowledge and belief, the person has not ceased to be an 
Irish citizen, 

is evidence that the person was an Irish citizen on the date on which the offence 
is alleged to have been committed, and is taken to have been signed by the person 
purporting to have signed it, unless the contrary is shown.

Question: How is the definition of “plan” in the 2011 Regulations amended by these Regulations with respect to planning instruments under the 2000 and 2024 Planning Acts?

Passages.Passage:
2. Regulation 2(1) of the European Communities (Birds and Natural 
Habitats) Regulations 2011 (S.I. No. 477 of 2011) is amended, in the definition 
of “plan”, by substituting “land use plan within the meaning of the Planning and 
Development Act 2000 (No. 30 of 2000) or a plan within the meaning of section 
198 of the Planning and Development Act 2024 (No. 34 of 2024)” for “land use 
plan within the meaning of the Planning Acts 2000 to 2011”.

Question: According to the Explanatory Note, why are plans within the meaning of section 198 of the Planning and Development Act 2024 excluded from the scope of the 2011 Regulations’ appropriate assessment requirements (save where a contrary intention appears)?

Passages.Passage:
These Regulations extend this exclusion from scope to also include 
“plans” within the meaning of section 198 of the Act of 2024. This amendment 
is on the basis that such plans (e.g. regional spatial and economic strategies, 
development plans) will be subject to appropriate assessment requirements 
under Chapter 2 of Part 6 of the Act of 2024 and therefore should not be within 
scope of the appropriate assessment requirements that apply to plans under the 
2011 Regulations (except where the contrary intention appears).
